Patterns

# 

<span key="1f9855c51f3142bb9a4c938c452b129e"><span offset-key="1f9855c51f3142bb9a4c938c452b129e:0">What are Patterns?</span></span>

## 

<span key="76d1bfa0acd7453f878906fd1a833a03"><span offset-key="76d1bfa0acd7453f878906fd1a833a03:0">Design Patterns</span></span>

<span key="88047eb0fbe64be689ad2c347d0b8b0a"><span offset-key="88047eb0fbe64be689ad2c347d0b8b0a:0">A </span>**design pattern**<span offset-key="88047eb0fbe64be689ad2c347d0b8b0a:2"> is a </span>**recipe for a solution to a common problem**<span offset-key="88047eb0fbe64be689ad2c347d0b8b0a:4">.</span></span>

<span key="61c5abeb7fa845688ceed7637665e1fa"><span offset-key="61c5abeb7fa845688ceed7637665e1fa:0">"Design pattern" is an overarching term covering more than just UI/UX design, and more than just software. For example, you'll probably hear the term most frequently in the context of approaching problems using object-oriented programmingâ€”and it has its origins in the realm of </span></span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Pattern_Language" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="449b44a39945483bb9d95d72f667b943" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-47611_259-47612-237__"><span data-key="0ddd157fb20a4c1398770d1a6fa3b49b"><span data-offset-key="0ddd157fb20a4c1398770d1a6fa3b49b:0">architecture and civil engineering (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="caba40f559a345d59f1a9128b9bcebe8"><span offset-key="caba40f559a345d59f1a9128b9bcebe8:0">.</span></span>

<span key="f4863a1c4af74665a4ad13a4bbb52d59"><span offset-key="f4863a1c4af74665a4ad13a4bbb52d59:0">Usually, you won't even see the term "design pattern" used to refer to UI/UX, since there are specific types of user interface and user experience patterns.</span></span>

<span key="e39be6c08d9a4891aa3e94da9e1bf39d"><span offset-key="e39be6c08d9a4891aa3e94da9e1bf39d:0">We're going to focus on those user-facing patterns hereâ€”approaches to recognizing common user situations, and accommodating them with well-established, repeatable solutions.</span></span>

# 

<span key="b964d5933393407da6ddf4068b0404a9"><span offset-key="b964d5933393407da6ddf4068b0404a9:0">UX Patterns</span></span>

## 

<span key="359ae63f6780435cb192367f1cc610f9"><span offset-key="359ae63f6780435cb192367f1cc610f9:0">UX Patterns: Modeling an Experience</span></span>

<span key="6cc0e9554f604961b68fd2e9986e612a"><span offset-key="6cc0e9554f604961b68fd2e9986e612a:0">Once we narrow our focus to UI/UX, the difference between a UX pattern and a UI pattern becomes subtle. Why is that?</span></span>

<span key="02f7334844904b01ae71279f5e798feb"><span offset-key="02f7334844904b01ae71279f5e798feb:0">Think about our definition of </span>*pattern*<span offset-key="02f7334844904b01ae71279f5e798feb:2">â€”a recipe for a solution to a common problem.</span></span>

<span key="38e3b62cb1894f8f81edd8bf5104e794"><span offset-key="38e3b62cb1894f8f81edd8bf5104e794:0">So much of what we design and build for a user experience is via a user interface. So naturally, a pattern to solve a </span>*user experience*<span offset-key="38e3b62cb1894f8f81edd8bf5104e794:2"> problem will often involve a </span>*user interface*<span offset-key="38e3b62cb1894f8f81edd8bf5104e794:4"> pattern.</span></span>

<span key="6e8346345fe04866a95cca1f9028d402"><span offset-key="6e8346345fe04866a95cca1f9028d402:0">But let's start by considering the general ways we can understand and start to model a user </span>*experience*<span offset-key="6e8346345fe04866a95cca1f9028d402:2">â€”the knowledge we have about what drives positive product experiences.</span></span>

## 

<span key="50e5a1f3310447718eb6fb27e4f7b7c9"><span offset-key="50e5a1f3310447718eb6fb27e4f7b7c9:0">Jakob's Law</span></span>

<span key="a6d631412e4541388c098954d5b2e43d"><span offset-key="a6d631412e4541388c098954d5b2e43d:0">In 2000, Jakob Nielsen of the Nielsen Norman Group </span></span><a href="https://www.nngroup.com/articles/end-of-web-design/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d561bc9d908c486d95bd08f1f7eed3e7" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-47611_259-47612-237__"><span data-key="67d2da7fd53c48259f8f88ec6af7234e"><span data-offset-key="67d2da7fd53c48259f8f88ec6af7234e:0">posited (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="7cc97a33f11a4124bc7d2f5e6357c88c"><span offset-key="7cc97a33f11a4124bc7d2f5e6357c88c:0">:</span></span>

> <span key="8d5270b99b3048e5abfa316499f47d27">**Users spend most of their time on** ***other*** **sites.**<span offset-key="8d5270b99b3048e5abfa316499f47d27:3"> This means that users prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.</span></span>

<span key="5c81df71c6654e7caca9208f38a17246"><span offset-key="5c81df71c6654e7caca9208f38a17246:0">Note that Nielsen isn't just talking about the way websites </span>*look*<span offset-key="5c81df71c6654e7caca9208f38a17246:2">â€”he's referring to how they </span>*work*<span offset-key="5c81df71c6654e7caca9208f38a17246:4">. In other words, in general, a user's experience with a website will be better if they don't have to learn new ways to interact with it. What's the takeaway here? </span>**Use UX patterns!**</span>

<span key="4dcb03558382411e8ddbd1abdbde0b30"><span offset-key="4dcb03558382411e8ddbd1abdbde0b30:0">Naturally, there's </span></span><a href="https://medium.cobeisfresh.com/jakobs-law-e368d03c7636" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f08cdf7196ee4f17a410ff4c388e1f83" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-47611_259-47612-237__"><span data-key="1888125727a549daa878e2b5326d0501"><span data-offset-key="1888125727a549daa878e2b5326d0501:0">some controversy (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="14f8e331941548888c4445f7888f9ca6"><span offset-key="14f8e331941548888c4445f7888f9ca6:0"> about taking Jakob's Law to its absolute conclusion. If we all want users to avoid having to experience different sites differently, then will all websites end up exactly the same?</span></span>

<span key="98b059471793494392ffb38e49a04ce2"><span offset-key="98b059471793494392ffb38e49a04ce2:0">Nonetheless, when you're designing a product and thinking about your user's experience, it can be a very useful rule of thumb: </span>***don't reinvent the wheel***<span offset-key="98b059471793494392ffb38e49a04ce2:2">. Default to the "boring" way to let your user experience your productâ€”</span>*then*<span offset-key="98b059471793494392ffb38e49a04ce2:4"> think about ways to tweak that experience if it makes sense for your product's goals.</span></span>

## 

<span key="1f092a351eb44024b480689f2be284c3"><span offset-key="1f092a351eb44024b480689f2be284c3:0">The Hook Model</span></span>

<span key="aa2d8d62fcee45e48d14a82802878629"><span offset-key="aa2d8d62fcee45e48d14a82802878629:0">In his influential 2014 book </span>*Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products*<span offset-key="aa2d8d62fcee45e48d14a82802878629:2">, Nir Eyal proposed </span></span><a href="https://www.nirandfar.com/how-to-manufacture-desire/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c38db6ac2a1040b089a3a0558abfa7bd" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-47611_259-47612-237__"><span data-key="e5e462d36ac041d49c3fe7b1fd8f1796"><strong>the Hook Model (Links to an external site.)</strong></span></span></a><span key="1ee8962f5f984a959f71f9c1605d2a1e"><span offset-key="1ee8962f5f984a959f71f9c1605d2a1e:0">.</span></span>

<span key="839766ff2bc74f54a3485554aa29d582"><span offset-key="839766ff2bc74f54a3485554aa29d582:0">The Hook model divides a user's interaction and experience with a product into four phases:</span></span>

1.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">1.</span>
    <span key="ccd4cb3d4d5544a1aaf4cd190ea9be94"><span offset-key="ccd4cb3d4d5544a1aaf4cd190ea9be94:0">A trigger to start using it</span></span>

2.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">2.</span>
    <span key="c288c83b06094782a5de885e5fc16a30"><span offset-key="c288c83b06094782a5de885e5fc16a30:0">An action that "satisfies" the trigger</span></span>

3.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">3.</span>
    <span key="fdebb19911dd4813b675767848842a38"><span offset-key="fdebb19911dd4813b675767848842a38:0">A reward for the action</span></span>

4.  <span class="r-1awozwy r-1nf4jbm r-6koalj r-18u37iz r-gg6oyi r-ubezar r-16dba41 r-135wba7 r-1m04atk r-1pyaxff" contenteditable="false" style="height:24px">4.</span>
    <span key="4980b3be3c544867a2cafb9a873eb609"><span offset-key="4980b3be3c544867a2cafb9a873eb609:0">An "investment" that makes the product more valuable to the user</span></span>

<span key="5b3a37f862b34810950e6ffec22ddbb6"><span offset-key="5b3a37f862b34810950e6ffec22ddbb6:0">Taken together, these phases of the Hook Model are a UX pattern. We're predicting ways that users will become engaged with our product via an experience we can engineer.</span></span>

<span key="433c8d42007c4d92b90e9cfc5254383f"><span offset-key="433c8d42007c4d92b90e9cfc5254383f:0">One thing to note here, howeverâ€”the Hook Model focuses on optimizing products for </span>*engagement*<span offset-key="433c8d42007c4d92b90e9cfc5254383f:2">â€”it doesn't necessarily optimize products for </span>*quality*<span offset-key="433c8d42007c4d92b90e9cfc5254383f:4">. In any case, though, keep it in mind as a valuable way to build a product experience that will keep users coming back.</span></span>

## 

<span key="d0d5608af2004b52877d9b08d161ff98"><span offset-key="d0d5608af2004b52877d9b08d161ff98:0">Gamification</span></span>

<span key="2ad987f4728e498cbcd59a553e81144a">**Gamification**<span offset-key="2ad987f4728e498cbcd59a553e81144a:1"> is incorporating game-like reward features into a product that isn't nominally a game.</span></span>

<span key="86bd572fb62f49aea0d1f315603e02c3"><span offset-key="86bd572fb62f49aea0d1f315603e02c3:0">One example of gamification is the Wikimedia Foundation's </span></span><a href="https://donate.wikimedia.org/wiki/Template:DonationBadges" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="cdb08a146a27411689f15941bad0fa5e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-47611_259-47612-237__"><span data-key="86a4581fb6054c5bae28c3df67ec6780"><span data-offset-key="86a4581fb6054c5bae28c3df67ec6780:0">donation badges (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="aa55d77214cf49a190bf54937a7e9fdb"><span offset-key="aa55d77214cf49a190bf54937a7e9fdb:0">â€”users who donate get recognized with a public badge (this also incorporates another useful concept: </span>**social proof**<span offset-key="aa55d77214cf49a190bf54937a7e9fdb:2">â€”giving your users examples of other people using your product in a certain way to encourage them to do so, too). Another frequent example is giving users points for completing certain actions, like filling in their profile information.</span></span>

<span key="eda495c34cb24804a7f04c08ce447c59"><span offset-key="eda495c34cb24804a7f04c08ce447c59:0">To drive positive product experiences, you'll want to ensure you're </span>**motivating**<span offset-key="eda495c34cb24804a7f04c08ce447c59:2"> your users, not manipulating themâ€”and that you're not relying on gamification alone to make the user experience great.</span></span>

## 

<span key="384d5b84208d453495ecf86883c74ab3"><span offset-key="384d5b84208d453495ecf86883c74ab3:0">The List Goes On...</span></span>

<span key="ee45e53131284ce0a7465d66eb3157ac"><span offset-key="ee45e53131284ce0a7465d66eb3157ac:0">There are hundreds of UX patterns out there, like:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="68c1d3306b92432f88bc5d0c6d85cb14"><span offset-key="68c1d3306b92432f88bc5d0c6d85cb14:0">ways to give feedback to the user</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="e30b944b39aa4e36b4d62018b0ba3bf9"><span offset-key="e30b944b39aa4e36b4d62018b0ba3bf9:0">ways to increase or decrease choices for the user</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="68fa2bdd82e24b028c901da7cc397bb8"><span offset-key="68fa2bdd82e24b028c901da7cc397bb8:0">ways to rely on or assist users' memory</span></span>

<span key="18b37371d6394ac9986a377a511c7a89"><span offset-key="18b37371d6394ac9986a377a511c7a89:0">If you want to read more about UX patterns, check out </span></span><a href="https://lawsofux.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="5f6d79292da444b5a126a7e0dcc62c9f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-47611_259-47612-237__"><span data-key="590bf93d59f4481a8f2fe0ef7b02f595"><strong>Laws of UX (Links to an external site.)</strong></span></span></a><span key="011b77bf05dd43f1ab98a4edb682276a"><span offset-key="011b77bf05dd43f1ab98a4edb682276a:0">, a really cool site laying out a bunch of research-driven UX principles and best practices.</span></span>

<span key="99c0c3265aec4d8e90ddb52e9d9d4ae9"><span offset-key="99c0c3265aec4d8e90ddb52e9d9d4ae9:0">We've barely scratched the surfaceâ€”but hopefully, these examples give you an idea of the work that has been done to understand user experiences, and to synthesize that knowledge into formulas for product success.</span></span>

# 

<span key="287b6ea9bdd44c5b90c51155e7d25f74"><span offset-key="287b6ea9bdd44c5b90c51155e7d25f74:0">UI Patterns</span></span>

## 

<span key="3c9d8a64dd044af7b0d786c758f4f60d"><span offset-key="3c9d8a64dd044af7b0d786c758f4f60d:0">UI Patterns: Implementing Paradigms</span></span>

<span key="f5886a47c4914c44950006b2c733b1da"><span offset-key="f5886a47c4914c44950006b2c733b1da:0">Now that we've examined general approaches to user experience problems, we can take some of those </span>**paradigms**<span offset-key="f5886a47c4914c44950006b2c733b1da:2">â€”models for thinking about thingsâ€”and see how we can implement them via user interfaces.</span></span>

## 

<span key="c65e2b962f644623a7831c5dde3438ac"><span offset-key="c65e2b962f644623a7831c5dde3438ac:0">Common UI Patterns</span></span>

<span key="b4954fbb300b41c39a328aeec9c5723c"><span offset-key="b4954fbb300b41c39a328aeec9c5723c:0">These frequently-used UI patterns combine structure, organization, and interaction behavior to meet users where they are and provide predictable, minimum-friction experiences. You'll almost certainly immediately recognize them!</span></span>

### 

<span key="6730cbaaf4ee445fb05687855cd57ed6"><span offset-key="6730cbaaf4ee445fb05687855cd57ed6:0">Pagination</span></span>

<span key="d9a89ccd0c77435c91066dc9a6c61047">**Pagination**<span offset-key="d9a89ccd0c77435c91066dc9a6c61047:1"> is splitting content up into pages. These aren't necessary separate screens or webpagesâ€”you'll usually deal with pagination when you're working with tables:</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="ed7379655a644ed1b2bb6239b7000217"><span offset-key="ed7379655a644ed1b2bb6239b7000217:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.27.19%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="07f69b0c94bd474d8f6549bf49563546"><span offset-key="07f69b0c94bd474d8f6549bf49563546:0">Pagination helps us avoid putting too much information in front of our users at once.</span></span>

<span key="56962e1b7fdf40b888d6c72fe0f42306"><span offset-key="56962e1b7fdf40b888d6c72fe0f42306:0">Note that to implement pagination, your product will often need to adjust the way it queries a databaseâ€”we'll probably only want to retrieve the "page" of data we're interested in displaying. This is called </span>**query pagination**<span offset-key="56962e1b7fdf40b888d6c72fe0f42306:2">. Pagination is thus a great example of how designing a user interface based on a user experience can result in a full-stack engineering featureâ€”the frontend and the backend will need to accommodate paginated queries in order to present this experience to the user.</span></span>

### 

<span key="7e6bb49d0fe94b3aa36a57f9fcaaedce"><span offset-key="7e6bb49d0fe94b3aa36a57f9fcaaedce:0">Progressive Disclosure</span></span>

<span key="774f016c900045649672732957df2e54">**Progressive disclosure**<span offset-key="774f016c900045649672732957df2e54:1"> is waiting to show content and/or prompt the user for action until it's needed. As the user continues toward a goal, they complete the process gradually. Pagination is an example of progressive disclosure!</span></span>

<span key="d4c060c1b28146bc9aefb2fe4d2f1e09"><span offset-key="d4c060c1b28146bc9aefb2fe4d2f1e09:0">Another example of progressive disclosure is using </span>**lazy forms**<span offset-key="d4c060c1b28146bc9aefb2fe4d2f1e09:2">â€”forms whose fields only appear once the user has filled in the previous field (or set of fields):</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="c765de5af2604b73b24671d405fdddac"><span offset-key="c765de5af2604b73b24671d405fdddac:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.35.39%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="d427f00c57cb4c07a38815d8594ef704"><span offset-key="d427f00c57cb4c07a38815d8594ef704:0">A related concept is using </span>**wizards**<span offset-key="d427f00c57cb4c07a38815d8594ef704:2">â€”walking the user through a process, with input fields or other required actions showing over multiple pages or screens:</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="a35c31a510244c87b3699e12d0daa524"><span offset-key="a35c31a510244c87b3699e12d0daa524:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.39.19%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="ee79cd9c19af4898a68c25300a864f70"><span offset-key="ee79cd9c19af4898a68c25300a864f70:0">Progressive disclosure prevents users from being intimidated by having to go through a lot of information or perform a lot of actions at once.</span></span>

### 

<span key="6230be5b5ecb4bbc85a0bbb476187560"><span offset-key="6230be5b5ecb4bbc85a0bbb476187560:0">Breadcrumbs</span></span>

<span key="41f100fe10444ffc98395bac846b5a72">**Breadcrumbs**<span offset-key="41f100fe10444ffc98395bac846b5a72:1"> are a very common UI pattern where we display a "secondary" navigation system to the user based on where they are in a hierarchy of pages or screens.</span></span>

<span key="703db03805be440799a3b43d29d67573"><span offset-key="703db03805be440799a3b43d29d67573:0">Note the breadcrumbs below (</span>`New Items`<span offset-key="703db03805be440799a3b43d29d67573:2"> â†’ </span>`Popular`<span offset-key="703db03805be440799a3b43d29d67573:4"> â†’ </span>`On Sale`<span offset-key="703db03805be440799a3b43d29d67573:6">):</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="3b6ec8c4ca0145db8aa2cd243529e019"><span offset-key="3b6ec8c4ca0145db8aa2cd243529e019:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.46.56%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="c0c5b0125f614ab7a3776adf3f12ad11"><span offset-key="c0c5b0125f614ab7a3776adf3f12ad11:0">Breadcrumbs both </span>**orient the user**<span offset-key="c0c5b0125f614ab7a3776adf3f12ad11:2"> and allow them to </span>**navigate in context**<span offset-key="c0c5b0125f614ab7a3776adf3f12ad11:4">.</span></span>

<span key="dfb71273e08c447d8a5246d330fbcc49"><span offset-key="dfb71273e08c447d8a5246d330fbcc49:0">In order to be usefully orienting, breadcrumbs should be based on the actual page or screen hierarchy (the way the content is actually organized) rather than whatever way the user has happened to navigate around (their </span>**history**<span offset-key="dfb71273e08c447d8a5246d330fbcc49:2">). That's because showing the hierarchy gives the user more information about how your product's content is structured.</span></span>

### 

<span key="4ec72f8d92a349939608e29999db7b00"><span offset-key="4ec72f8d92a349939608e29999db7b00:0">Empty States</span></span>

<span key="e8f852d754b54956b26fdbc210daaaae">**Empty states**<span offset-key="e8f852d754b54956b26fdbc210daaaae:1"> are an extremely useful pattern that tells the user: "There's nothing here </span>*right now*<span offset-key="e8f852d754b54956b26fdbc210daaaae:3">â€”but there could be!"</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h" />

Could not load image

<span key="c5fccf9cee3844e2b5198abc27e30b3b"><span offset-key="c5fccf9cee3844e2b5198abc27e30b3b:0">Screen%20Shot%202021-08-29%20at%208.52.28%20PM.png</span></span>

<span key="45140614673e4f5a9d12334b6d0dc249"><span offset-key="45140614673e4f5a9d12334b6d0dc249:0">Empty states are highly orienting for users, because it tells them both how they should be interacting with your product, and what to expect both in the short term and the long term.</span></span>

<span key="93b684eebc45401f8b68c5da848e234b"><span offset-key="93b684eebc45401f8b68c5da848e234b:0">If your users will land on a screen where data </span>*could*<span offset-key="93b684eebc45401f8b68c5da848e234b:2"> be displayed, but there currently isn't anything to show themâ€”you'll </span>*almost certainly*<span offset-key="93b684eebc45401f8b68c5da848e234b:4"> want to show them an empty state.</span></span>

## 

<span key="771ace5002bd4fbdbbbe62f8ce62c6d6"><span offset-key="771ace5002bd4fbdbbbe62f8ce62c6d6:0">Further Reading</span></span>

<span key="6237dd90e1654a37876cb8ede4be7ce6"><span offset-key="6237dd90e1654a37876cb8ede4be7ce6:0">There's no way we could list out all the possible UI patterns availableâ€”there are probably thousands!</span></span>

<span key="332fd9ee73d240158285074382ef57f4"><span offset-key="332fd9ee73d240158285074382ef57f4:0">To see more and learn more about UI patterns, check out these resources:</span></span>
